At that time, King Prasenajit was staying in the city of UjjayinÄ«. A certain elder had recently married and left his wife in his original house, while he himself went to do business and carry goods to other places.
After her husband left, the wife indulged in clothing and food, and her afflictions increased greatly. She then ascended a tower and looked around at men, gazing without rest day after day.

Later, at another time, King Prasenajit rode a fragrant elephant past the house. The woman, having seen him, gave rise to a mind of sexual desire, and then threw a flower garland from afar, which landed on the king's shoulder.
The king looked up and saw a young girl, her appearance upright and radiant, looking around with self-conceit.
Seeing this, the king knew she was lustful and said to her:
Young girl!
If you have love in your heart, why not come out for a while?
She replied:

The king's mind was deluded and he could not move forward. He then dismounted from the elephant and entered her house. Feeling joyful, he immediately became pregnant.
A wise woman has five things:
First, she knows whether a man has lustful thoughts or not;
Second, she knows the right time;
Third, she knows when she receives a fetus and knows whose fetus it is;
Fourth, she knows if it is a boy;
Fifth, she knows if it is a girl.
She then said to the king:
Does the king know?

At that time, the king immediately gave her a necklace of genuine pearls and told her:
If you give birth to a daughter, you can keep it yourself. If it is a son, give this necklace to him and send him to me.
The woman respectfully agreed, and the king left.
After several months, the signs of pregnancy became apparent on the outside. At that time, her former husband wrote a letter saying:
You should be at ease. I expect to return to my hometown before long.
When the woman heard this, she became greatly worried and sent a message to the king, saying:
I am already pregnant. My former husband is coming now. What should I do?
The king sent a message saying:
You should be at ease. I have a way to prevent him from coming.
The woman then remained silent.
The king sent a message to her former husband:

After traveling a long distance for many years, the woman's month was full and she gave birth to a son, whose appearance was admirable and rare for the times.

At dawn, she filled his mouth with ghee and honey, placed him in a box with soft cotton, covered him with a white cloth, hung pearl necklaces on top, sealed the box tightly, fastened it with a red ribbon, and stamped it with a purple seal. She told the maid,
Take this box to the king's gate, wipe a platform clean, place the box on top, light a lamp beside it, and wait there. When someone takes it away, you can return.

He held the child and gave it to the queen, saying:

After the queen obtained it, she made a vow, saying:

At that time, in the country of Taká¹£aÅ›ilÄ in the north, there was a king named Samá¹›ddhi, who ruled the country with peace and prosperity, and the people were flourishing, as explained elsewhere. The king then personally assembled the four divisions of his army and headed towards the country of UjjayinÄ«. As he gradually reached the city, he plundered without restraint, causing harm and injustice, making it difficult for people to survive.

When King Prasenajit heard that the enemy had arrived, he also strictly assembled the four divisions of his army to go out and fight them. Prasenajit was not victorious, and his troops were scattered. He then fled on a single horse to another place.
In the wilderness, he saw a plowman named VardhamÄna plowing the field himself. The king observed that his appearance was different from other people and asked him,

The plowman did not know that this person was King Prasenajit, so he said to him,ğŸ”½If you are King Prasenajit, why are you fleeing on a single horse?

Before he finished speaking, his wife came to serve food, sewing leaves into a vessel. The husband immediately washed his hands and was about to eat, but looked at the king and said:
A valiant man, briefly observing the situation, seems to have a hungry look. I, a poor person, have this coarse meal. If you do not dislike it, please share it with me.
At that time, King Má¹›gÄá¹…ka thought like this:

He then dismounted, took a seat on the king's back, washed his hands and feet, and ate together in one place. His wife then poured wine into a chipped earthenware cup for him to drink.
The king thought like this:
Although I know the cup is chipped, I will drink from the unchipped part.
The king was wise and skilled in timely affairs. He thought again:
If I drink from the undamaged part, he might say I am deceiving him. I should now drink from the damaged part to make him feel deeply fond of me.
At that time, the plowman first drank from the broken part to ward off the poison himself, and then passed it to the king. The king obtained it and drank from the broken part as well.
The plowman thought:
This great man has no reservations in his feelings. He drinks from the broken part as if it were the undamaged part. I should now deeply respect him, so that our friendship may last for a long time.
Thinking like this, he said to his wife:
My dear!

This great man is a dear friend who has won my favor. You can take him to our former poor house, oil his body, bathe him with hot water, prepare food and drink for him, and give the horse good water and grass to his heart's content.
The wife then took him back home and did as he said. They became close and she provided for his needs.
At that time, there was a small country of King CÄ«rá¹‡aprabha called KÄsÄ«. It came to plunder and harass the people.

Then King CÄ«rá¹‡aprabha, having read the letter, thought like this:

I hope to sit knee to knee, exchange hearts, and fully express our unreserved friendship, as if nothing has happened. I will then return to my former city.
When the ministers received the letter, they discussed together:
If we tell the king there is no one, he will certainly deceive us. We should devise a strategy and for now respond to the situation.
They composed a letter in reply, saying:
Friend!

Although you have untied the seal, your deep affection is sincere. Although the matter is true, how can there be no hesitation? The two countries are in the same gathering, each giving rise to suspicion. Although I have come against my will, I have no leisure to go out.
However, this prince named Gopa is my son. I will let him come out to see you and fully express our joyful intentions. You may stay or leave as you please.

At that time, they immediately ordered Gopa to come out and see RÄá¹£á¹­rapÄla. With joyful hearts, they fully expressed their feelings. The siege was lifted and the flag returned to the original country.
At that time, King Prasenajit and his ministers discussed together, saying:
Enemies from other places have scattered like rain, and we must urgently search for our own king.
Horse messengers from the four directions pursued him.
When King Prasenajit heard that VarÅ›ÄkÄra had withdrawn his troops, he told the plowman Pá¹›thu:

He replied:

The king said:

When you enter the city, you should ask like this:
'Where is the house of the man with many horses?'
Having said this, he urged his horse forward. When he reached the gate of his own city, he told the gatekeeper:

Later, at a different time, in the city of UjjayinÄ« there was a great festival, and people from far and near all gathered in the city.
Then the husband and wife told their husband:

The husband said:
Wise one!
How can all the wealthy people be real?
One can see them in three places:
First, when they are defeated in battle by others; second, when they are deceived by others; third, when they lose their country as the ruler of a state. How else can one see them?
The wife said:

The couple then left.
When they arrived in the city, the farmer thought:

He told the gatekeeper,ğŸ”½Hey!
Man!

At that time, the gatekeeper, having heard his words, then took the couple and sent them to the king. As soon as the king saw them from afar, he was startled and exclaimed with joy,

He further said,
VardhamÄna!

He replied,

VardhamÄna saw the king sitting on a lion throne, surrounded by ministers, and although he had not yet recognized them well, he thought in his mind, not knowing why he was detained here.

The king knew he had doubts and wanted him to remember the past, so he immediately got off the seat, took off his heavenly crown, and showed his forehead. VardhamÄna, having seen it, remembered his appearance, and the couple prostrated at the king's feet at the same time.

At that time, the king immediately arranged a grand ceremony, led him into the inner palace, bathed him with fragrant hot water, dressed him in exquisite clothes, and served him a hundred kinds of delicacies.
The king personally observed his eating. After the meal, he invited him to a magnificent palace, with brocade curtains and fragrant flowers, and let him rest comfortably in a timely manner.
The king ordered the inner palace, saying:
This is my father and mother. Whatever they need, such as food, drink, clothing, bedding, male and female servants, all should be provided.
At that time, King Prasenajit, after showing respect to him, everyone also showed respect. The prince, ministers, and people inside and outside all respected him.
The farmer Vá¹›á¹£a, having seen this unexpected respect and offerings, felt ashamed after seven days and said to the king:

The king then forcefully established him as the great minister of state.

He replied:
Great king!

Later, on another occasion, because there was a court gathering, the king, wanting to make the ministers and nobles respect Nourished, skillfully asked a question:

At that time, a great minister proposed:

After bathing, he did not go to the king's appointment, but went to eat.

The messenger went to report to the king, and after the king heard it, he himself rode a great elephant to the man's house and asked:

Each gave rise to wonder and looked at each other with wide eyes.
At that time, the king then washed his hands and feet, and they all ate together in one place. The people in the house, seeing this, were all frightened and said to each other:

The king said:

He replied:

On another occasion, when Upagu was traveling along the road, he saw two poor boys without relatives or dependents, playing with slings and marbles on the road.

At that time, Upagu saw this from afar and felt it was very unusual. He thought:
